natural problem:
Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. For example, for the row $\text{GBBGGGBGBGGGBGBGGBGG}$ we have that $S=12$. The average value of $S$ (if all possible orders of these 20 people are considered) is closest to
$\text{(A)}\ 9\qquad\text{(B)}\ 10\qquad\text{(C)}\ 11\qquad\text{(D)}\ 12\qquad\text{(E)}\ 13$
natural solution: We approach this problem using Linearity of Expectation. Consider a pair of two people standing next to each other. Ignoring all other people, the probability that a boy is standing on the left position and a girl is standing on the right position is $\frac7{20}\cdot\frac{13}{19}$.
Similarly, if a girl is standing on the left position and a boy is standing on the right position the probability is also $\frac{7\cdot 13}{20\cdot 19}$.

Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: real
assumes h0 : "7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row"
and h1 : "S = (\<Sum> arrangement \<in> all arrangements of 20 people. count adjacent boy-girl pairs in arrangement) / (number of all arrangements)"
and h2 : "\<forall> A B C D E. A=9 \<and> B=10 \<and> C=11 \<and> D=12 \<and> E=13"
shows  "S \<approx> 9"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 The final Answer is 9

 Similarly, if a girl is standing on the left position and a boy is standing on the right position the probability is also $\frac{7\cdot 13}{20\cdot 19}$.
 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.

theorem
fixes S :: real
assumes h0 : "7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row"
and h1 : "S = (\<Sum> arrangement \<in> all arrangements of 20 people. count adjacent boy-girl pairs in arrangement) / (number of all arrangements)"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a row of 7 boys and 13 girls, find the average number of adjacent boy-girl pairs in all possible arrangements of the 20 people. The final answer is approximately 9.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: real and avg_S :: real
assumes h0 : "7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row"
and h1 : "S is the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other"
and h2 : "avg_S is the average value of S for all possible orders of these 20 people"
and h3 : "avg_S is closest to 9"
shows  "avg_S = 9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. For example, for the row $\text{GBBGGGBGBGGGBGBGGBGG}$ we have that $S=12$. The average value of $S$ (if all possible orders of these 20 people are considered) is closest to

 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: real and avg_S :: real
assumes h0 : "7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row"
and h1 : "S is the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other"
and h2 : "avg_S is the average value of S for all possible orders of these 20 people"
and h3 : "avg_S is closest to 9"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a row of 20 people, there are 7 boys and 13 girls. If we consider all possible orders of these people, what is the average number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other? The closest integer to the average is 9.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls S :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 7"
and h1 : "girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>row | (\<forall>i. row i = Boy \<or> row i = Girl) \<and> (\<forall>i. row i = Boy \<longrightarrow> row (i+1) \<noteq> Boy) \<and> (\<forall>i. row i = Girl \<longrightarrow> row (i+1) \<noteq> Girl)\<rbrakk> count_adjacent_pairs row) / (fact boys * fact girls)"
shows  "\<lfloor>S\<rfloor> = 9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. For example, for the row $\text{GBBGGGBGBGGGBGBGGBGG}$ we have that $S=12$. The average value of $S$ (if all possible orders of these 20 people are considered) is closest to
$\text{(A)}\ 9\qquad\text{(B)}\ 10\qquad\text{(C)}\ 11\qquad\text{(D)}\ 12\qquad\text{(E)}\ 13$
 The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We approach this problem using Linearity of Expectation. Consider a pair of two people standing next to each other. Ignoring all other people, the probability that a boy is standing on the left position and a girl is standing on the right position is $\frac7{20}\cdot\frac{13}{19}$.
 Similarly, if a girl is standing on the left position and a boy is standing on the right position the probability is also $\frac{7\cdot 13}{20\cdot 19}$.
 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls S :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 7"
and h1 : "girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>row | (\<forall>i. row i = Boy \<or> row i = Girl) \<and> (\<forall>i. row i = Boy \<longrightarrow> row (i+1) \<noteq> Boy) \<and> (\<forall>i. row i = Girl \<longrightarrow> row (i+1) \<noteq> Girl)\<rbrakk> count_adjacent_pairs row) / (fact boys * fact girls)"
shows  "\<lfloor>S\<rfloor> = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 7 boys and 13 girls sitting in a row. If no two boys or two girls can sit next to each other, how many ways can they be seated? The final answer is 9.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: real
assumes h0 : "average S = (\<Sum>x\<in>all_permutations. count_neighboring_boy_girl x) / card all_permutations"
and h1 : "7 boys and 13 girls are considered"
shows  "rounded_average_S = 9"
a_3.formal solution:

 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. fixes S :: real

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: real and n_boys n_girls :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_boys = 7"
and h1 : "n_girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>row \<in> {R. length R = 20 \<and> count_list R ''B'' = n_boys \<and> count_list R ''G'' = n_girls}. 
                  (\<Sum>i \<in> {0..<19}. if R!i = ''B'' \<and> R!(i+1) = ''G'' \<or> R!i = ''G'' \<and> R!(i+1) = ''B'' then 1 else 0))"
and h3 : "avg_S = (\<Sum>row \<in> {R. length R = 20 \<and> count_list R ''B'' = n_boys \<and> count_list R ''G'' = n_girls}. S) / 
                 (fact (n_boys + n_girls) / (fact n_boys * fact n_girls))"
shows  "round avg_S = 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. For example, for the row $\text{GBBGGGBGBGGGBGBGGBGG}$ we have that $S=12$. The average value of $S$ (if all possible orders of these 20 people are considered) is closest to
$\text{(A)}\ 9\qquad\text{(B)}\ 10\qquad\text{(C)}\ 11\qquad\text{(D)}\ 12\qquad\text{(E)}\ 13$
 The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We approach this problem using Linearity of Expectation. Consider a pair of two people standing next to each other. Ignoring all other people, the probability that a boy is standing on the left position and a girl is standing on the right position is $\frac7{20}\cdot\frac{13}{19}$.

 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: real and n_boys n_girls :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_boys = 7"
and h1 : "n_girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>row \<in> {R. length R = 20 \<and> count_list R ''B'' = n_boys \<and> count_list R ''G'' = n_girls}. 
                  (\<Sum>i \<in> {0..<19}. if R!i = ''B'' \<and> R!(i+1) = ''G'' \<or> R!i = ''G'' \<and> R!(i+1) = ''B'' then 1 else 0))"
and h3 : "avg_S = (\<Sum>row \<in> {R. length R = 20 \<and> count_list R ''B'' = n_boys \<and> count_list R ''G'' = n_girls}. S) / 
                 (fact (n_boys + n_girls) / (fact n_boys * fact n_girls))"
shows  "round avg_S = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a row of 20 children, there are 7 boys and 13 girls. Calculate the average number of boy-girl or girl-boy pairs in all possible arrangements of the children in a row. The final answer is approximately 9.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> rows. rows = 7 * boys + 13 * girls"
and h1 : "\<forall> rows. S = number of places where boys and girls are next to each other"
and h2 : "average S = (sum S) / (number of possible orders)"
shows  "average S closest to 9"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other.  Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> rows. rows = 7 * boys + 13 * girls"
and h1 : "\<forall> rows. S = number of places where boys and girls are next to each other"
and h2 : "average S = (sum S) / (number of possible orders)"
shows  "average S closest to 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a row of children, there are 7 boys and 13 girls. If we randomly arrange the children in a row, find the average number of places where a boy and a girl are seated next to each other. The final answer is closest to 9.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls S avg_S :: real
assumes h0 : "boys = 7"
and h1 : "girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>(i :: nat) | i \<in> {1..girls * boys}. (i > 0 \<and> i < girls * boys) \<and> (i mod boys = 0 \<or> i mod girls = 0))"
and h3 : "avg_S = S / (factorial (boys + girls) / (factorial boys * factorial girls))"
shows  "floor avg_S = 9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. For example, for the row $\text{GBBGGGBGBGGGBGBGGBGG}$ we have that $S=12$. The average value of $S$ (if all possible orders of these 20 people are considered) is closest to
$\text{(A)}\ 9\qquad\text{(B)}\ 10\qquad\text{(C)}\ 11\qquad\text{(D)}\ 12\qquad\text{(E)}\ 13$
 The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We approach this problem using Linearity of Expectation. Consider a pair of two people standing next to each other. Ignoring all other people, the probability that a boy is standing on the left position and a girl is standing on the right position is $\frac7{20}\cdot\frac{13}{19}$.
 Similarly, if a girl is standing on the left position and a boy is standing on the right position the probability is also $\frac{7\cdot 13}{20\cdot 19}$.
 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls S avg_S :: real
assumes h0 : "boys = 7"
and h1 : "girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>(i :: nat) | i \<in> {1..girls * boys}. (i > 0 \<and> i < girls * boys) \<and> (i mod boys = 0 \<or> i mod girls = 0))"
and h3 : "avg_S = S / (factorial (boys + girls) / (factorial boys * factorial girls))"
shows  "floor avg_S = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a group of 7 boys and 13 girls, find the average number of distinct pairs that can be formed where either the boy or the girl is in the pair, but not both. Round down the answer to the nearest whole number. The final answer is 9.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls S :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 7"
and h1 : "girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>order\<in>set (permute_list (replicate boys 'B' @ replicate girls 'G')). count_adjacent_pairs (\<lambda>(x, y). x = 'B' \<and> y = 'G' \<or> x = 'G' \<and> y = 'B') order) div (fact (boys + girls))"
shows  "S = 9"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Similarly, if a girl is standing on the left position and a boy is standing on the right position the probability is also $\frac{7\cdot 13}{20\cdot 19}$.
 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls S :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 7"
and h1 : "girls = 13"
and h2 : "S = (\<Sum>order\<in>set (permute_list (replicate boys 'B' @ replicate girls 'G')). count_adjacent_pairs (\<lambda>(x, y). x = 'B' \<and> y = 'G' \<or> x = 'G' \<and> y = 'B') order) div (fact (boys + girls))"
shows  "S = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a group of 7 boys and 13 girls, find the average number of adjacent boy-girl pairs when the children are arranged in a random order. The final answer is 9.

fixes S :: int
assumes h0 : "S = num_adjacent_pairs (7, 13)"
and h1 : "average S = closest_average"
and h2 : "closest_average = min_dist_to_avg {9, 10, 11, 12, 13}"
shows  "closest_average = 9"
a_8.formal solution:

fixes S :: int
assumes h0 : "S = num_adjacent_pairs (7, 13)"
and h1 : "average S = closest_average"
and h2 : "closest_average = min_dist_to_avg {9, 10, 11, 12, 13}"
shows  "closest_average = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a set of numbers {9, 10, 11, 12, 13}, find the average of the closest pair of adjacent numbers. If the pair is defined by the numbers 7 and 13, what is the closest average? The final answer is 9.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: nat
assumes h0 : "S = (\<Sum>row | row is a permutation of 7 boys and 13 girls. count_adjacent_pairs row)"
and h1 : "average S = (\<Sum>S) / (fact 20)"
shows  "round (average S) = 9"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that 7 boys and 13 girls line up in a row. Let $S$ be the number of places in the row where a boy and a girl are standing next to each other. For example, for the row $\text{GBBGGGBGBGGGBGBGGBGG}$ we have that $S=12$. The average value of $S$ (if all possible orders of these 20 people are considered) is closest to

 The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We approach this problem using Linearity of Expectation. Consider a pair of two people standing next to each other. Ignoring all other people, the probability that a boy is standing on the left position and a girl is standing on the right position is $\frac7{20}\cdot\frac{13}{19}$.

 Thus, the total probability of the two people being one boy and one girl is $\frac{91}{190}$. There are a total of 19 different adjacent pairs, so by Linearity of Expectation, we have that the expected value of $S$ is $\frac{91}{10}$ so $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: nat
assumes h0 : "S = (\<Sum>row | row is a permutation of 7 boys and 13 girls. count_adjacent_pairs row)"
and h1 : "average S = (\<Sum>S) / (fact 20)"
shows  "round (average S) = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a row of 20 students, there are 7 boys and 13 girls. Find the average number of adjacent pairs of boys when all possible permutations of the students are considered. Round your answer to the nearest whole number. The final answer is 9.
